name: The Umbrella
description_html: Umbrellas became a defining symbol of the 2014 Hong Kong pro-democracy protests – soon dubbed the “Umbrella Movement” or “Umbrella Revolution”. When police first fired tear-gas canisters at student-led sit-ins on 28 September 2014, demonstrators instinctively raised umbrellas to block pepper spray, rubber bullets, and the blazing midday sun, turning an everyday accessory into an emblem of passive resistance and the fight for universal suffrage. Images of pastel-colored canopies clustered outside government headquarters in Admiralty – and later across Mong Kok and Causeway Bay – spread worldwide, capturing the movement’s creativity and determination. Yellow umbrellas, especially, became shorthand for the cause: they appeared in protest art, were projected onto skyscrapers, and even inspired the 3-metre-tall “Umbrella Man” statue erected in the occupied streets. Beyond defence, umbrellas served as makeshift banners for slogans such as “I want real democracy,” and were lashed together into improvised barricades or held high to shield protesters’ faces from surveillance cameras. The symbolism soon travelled: activists in Myanmar, Thailand, and elsewhere have since wielded umbrellas in their own demonstrations, using them both for physical protection and as a vivid visual link to Hong Kong’s precedent.

images.caption: Yellow umbrellas outside government headquarters, Admiralty, 2014
Crowd assembled during sit-in, Mong Kok
A line of umbrellas forming a barrier
A line of umbrellas forming a barrier
Short clip: umbrella moment (YouTube)

eyewitness: I was standing near Admiralty when the students first raised umbrellas — the crowd was calm but determined. (Anonymous eyewitness, 2014)
Several people I spoke with described how umbrellas were used both to shield from tear gas and to protect identities from cameras.
sources: Chan, L. (2015). Visual symbols in protest movements. Journal of Social Movements.

name: The White Head Scarf
description_html: In 1977 Argentina’s Mothers of Plaza de Mayo donned white scarves—evoking diapers—to mark the innocence of children who disappeared under military rule. Their weekly marches in Buenos Aires turned the scarf into a global emblem of the quest for truth and justice. In Iran, white scarves signal defiance of compulsory hijab laws. Spurred by #WhiteWednesdays, women wore or waved white scarves to protest mandatory veiling. The gesture drew worldwide attention in 2017 when Vida Movahed, the “Girl of Enghelab Street,” stood unveiled and brandished her scarf, inspiring similar protests and arrests.

name: The Blank Sheet of Paper
description_html: A white piece of paper, or blank sheet, has become a powerful symbol of protest against censorship and repression, most notably during the 2022 anti-lockdown demonstrations in China. Protesters held up blank sheets to silently express everything they were forbidden to say, making the absence of words a direct metaphor for silenced voices and government control. The tactic originated earlier in the 2019–2020 Hong Kong protests, where demonstrators used blank paper after protest slogans were banned. The symbol has since appeared in other countries.

name: Vinegar
description_html: Vinegar became an emblematic tool during the 2013 protests in Brazil, often called the “Vinegar Protests” (Revolta do Vinagre). Protesters carried bottles of vinegar, believing that breathing through a cloth soaked in vinegar could help neutralize the effects of tear gas and pepper spray used by police, though its medical effectiveness is debated. The tactic became so widespread that police arrested over 60 people for carrying vinegar, including journalists, turning the substance into a symbol of resistance and sparking sarcastic nicknames like “the vinegar march”.

name: Brazilian football jersey
description_html: The yellow Brazilian football jersey, traditionally a unifying national symbol, has been controversially co-opted as a protest symbol in recent years. Most notably, supporters of former President Jair Bolsonaro adopted the jersey during political rallies and protests, including the storming of government buildings in Brasília in January 2023. The jersey, once seen as non-partisan, became closely linked to right-wing and nationalist movements, leading to widespread controversy and debate over its meaning. The Brazilian Football Confederation publicly condemned the politicization of the jersey, emphasizing its intended role to unite, not divide, Brazilians.

name: Keys
description_html: In Czech protests, especially those harkening back to the 1989 Velvet Revolution, rattling keys became a symbolic act of defiance, representing the end of Communist-era surveillance (keys to locked-down lives) and a call for transparency, with protesters shaking them in squares like Wenceslas Square to demand change and echo democratic ideals. This tradition continues in modern demonstrations, linking current demands for accountability (like against then-PM Babiš in 2019) with the legacy of freedom from 1989.

name: Fireworks
description_html: During Georgia’s 2024–25 pro-EU protests, fireworks have become both rallying beacon and improvised weapon. Night after night in Tbilisi—and in smaller rallies in Batumi and Kutaisi—thousands launch rockets skyward or toward police cordons outside parliament. The crackling bursts energise crowds, mask tear-gas plumes, and disrupt water-cannon advances. Protesters frame the pyrotechnics as a non-lethal form of self-defence and defiance; riot police answer with tear gas, stun grenades, and mass arrests. The salvos have so unsettled officials that Prime Minister Irakli Kobakhidze has ordered an emergency ban on retail fireworks, accusing shops of “arming a revolution,” while rights groups argue the measure merely criminalises dissent. In this clash of light and law, fireworks have come to symbolise the creativity—and determination—of Georgia’s EU-leaning generation.

name: The Watermelon
description_html: The watermelon has become a creative stand-in for the Palestinian flag: its red flesh, green rind, white pith, and black seeds echo the flag’s four colours. After Israel outlawed public displays of the Palestinian flag and even its colour combination following the 1967 Six-Day War, Palestinians began painting, carrying, and photographing watermelon slices to sidestep the ban and signal national identity. The fruit soon appeared in murals, posters, and street rallies. During the 2023 Gaza conflict, its image and emoji spread globally online, letting supporters show solidarity and evade censorship when the flag itself was still forbidden.

name: The Coat Hanger
description_html: A coat hanger is a powerful and enduring symbol in abortion rights protests, representing the dangers of unsafe, illegal abortions. Its origins as a protest icon date back to the pre-Roe v. Wade era in the United States, when women sometimes resorted to using wire coat hangers to self-induce abortions due to lack of access to safe medical procedures. The coat hanger thus serves as a stark warning of the life-threatening risks women face when abortion is criminalized. Activists have prominently featured coat hangers in demonstrations, such as the 1969 Washington march where protesters wore them around their necks and in more recent actions, including sending hangers to the U.S. Supreme Court. In Poland, coat hangers have also become a central visual element in protests against abortion bans. During the 2016 “Black Monday” strike and subsequent demonstrations, Polish women held up wire coat hangers to represent the peril of illegal abortions, warning against the consequences of restrictive legislation. The use of coat hangers in both American and Polish contexts underscores their role as a universal symbol of resistance to abortion bans and a call for safe, legal reproductive healthcare.

name: Chrysanthemums & Asters
description_html: Chrysanthemums and their close relative, asters, have occasionally served as protest emblems, drawing on their associations with remembrance or peaceful resistance. The clearest political use came in Hungary’s 1918 Aster Revolution, when supporters pinned asters to their coats while proclaiming the First Hungarian People’s Republic. In East Asia, white chrysanthemums—long linked to mourning—appear at vigils such as Hong Kong’s annual Tiananmen commemorations, honoring those lost in political struggle. A famous Western image is Marc Riboud’s 1967 photograph from the March on the Pentagon, showing 17-year-old Jan Rose Kasmir holding a chrysanthemum in front of soldiers’ bayonets, powerfully representing peaceful resistance during the anti–Vietnam War movement.

name: The Spoon
description_html: The spoon emerged as a powerful symbol of Palestinian resistance following the dramatic escape of six Palestinian prisoners from Israel’s high-security Gilboa Prison in September 2021. According to reports, the escapees used spoons, along with plates and kettle handles, to dig a tunnel from their cell, evading security measures and sparking widespread admiration. The event quickly inspired artists, activists, and demonstrators, who began featuring spoons in protest art, sculptures, and public rallies as an emblem of determination, ingenuity, and the struggle for freedom.

name: The Wooden Spoon
description_html: In Slovakia, the wooden spoon has become a prominent symbol in protests against the restriction of reproductive rights. During demonstrations opposing stricter abortion laws in 2020, organizers encouraged participants to bring wooden spoons—alongside pots and brooms—as a representation of care, domestic labor, and civil disobedience. The spoons were often customized with messages, symbolizing both the everyday work of women and resistance to political attempts to control their bodies. In Burkina Faso, the wooden spoon has also been used as a protest symbol, particularly by women who bang them against pots to make noise and draw attention to their demands. This act, rooted in local traditions, highlights the role of women in civic action and protest.

name: The Rubber Duck
description_html: Rubber ducks became an iconic symbol of Thailand’s pro-democracy protests in 2020. Initially brought to demonstrations as a humorous response to government barricades, inflatable yellow ducks quickly gained prominence when protesters used them as improvised shields against police water cannons and tear gas during violent clashes near parliament. Their cheerful, fragile appearance contrasted with their new role as protectors, capturing public imagination and inspiring widespread protest art and memes.

name: The Yellow Ribbon
description_html: Yellow ribbons have historically symbolized hope for a loved one’s safe return. In the 1980s, they became a sign of democratization in the Philippines. After the 2014 Sewol Ferry disaster in South Korea, they spread online as a symbol of hope, later evolving into a protest icon as public anger toward the government grew, representing grief and the demand for accountability. Since 2022, Ukraine’s “Yellow Ribbon” resistance movement has used the symbol in russian-occupied territories. Tied in public spaces, the ribbons express support for Ukrainian sovereignty and serve as quiet signs of unity and nonviolent resistance.

name: The Water Jug
description_html: The water jug has emerged as an unexpected symbol in pro-Palestinian protests across the United States, particularly during the wave of student-led demonstrations in 2024 and 2025. Its rise began with viral incidents at university protests, most notably at California Polytechnic State University, Humboldt, where a protester struck a police officer with a large, empty water jug. The moment, captured on video, quickly spread across social media, where the jug was dubbed the “Jug of Justice” and became an emblem of grassroots resistance. Protesters began bringing water jugs to demonstrations, using them as makeshift shields, tools for practical needs, and a symbol of anti-police sentiment and solidarity with the Palestinian cause.

name: Tape
description_html: Tape has become a stark protest symbol. Protesters often place tape over their mouths to represent censorship, forced silence, or the suppression of free speech, making visible the experience of being silenced by authorities or unjust laws. Another notable example of tape’s symbolic use occurred during the 2003 Cricket World Cup when Zimbabwean players Andy Flower and Henry Olonga, lacking black armbands, wore strips of black insulating tape to “mourn the death of democracy,” drawing global attention to government repression. This highlights how an ordinary item can instantly signal profound political dissent.

name: Eggs
description_html: The act of throwing eggs at people or property has a long history as a protest tactic, especially against politicians and public figures. The intention is typically to humiliate the target rather than cause physical harm, turning them into figures of ridicule and signaling moral objection to their actions or presence. Notable incidents include the egging of Winston Churchill by a suffragette in 1910, and various politicians like Richard Nixon, Harold Wilson, and Scott Morrison. Egging is considered vandalism and can result in legal consequences, especially if property is damaged or injuries occur.

name: Flour
description_html: Flour bombing is a classic protest method involving the throwing of flour, often contained in paper bags, at people or objects. This tactic is used to create an inconvenient and messy stain, serving as a form of public humiliation or disruption. Flour bombs have been used alongside eggs in protests against politicians like Tony Blair and Emmanuel Macron, and during major demonstrations, such as the 1981 Springbok Tour in New Zealand. Historically, flour has also been central to food riots, such as the 1837 Flour Riot in New York City, where public anger over rising prices led to mass looting and destruction of flour stores. The tactic remains a simple, non-lethal way to achieve maximum disruption.

name: Soup
description_html: Soup has become a notable tool in climate and social justice protests, particularly in high-profile actions targeting famous artworks in museums. Activists have thrown soup at protected paintings such as Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa and Vincent van Gogh’s Sunflowers to draw attention to issues like environmental policy and food security. These acts are intended to provoke public debate and highlight the perceived imbalance between the protection of art and urgent social needs. The protests often include statements demanding systemic changes, such as the right to healthy and sustainable food, and are orchestrated by groups aiming to integrate food justice into broader social security systems. The artworks themselves are typically unharmed due to protective glass coverings.

name: Cake and Pie
description_html: Throwing cakes and pies at public figures is a long-standing protest tactic used to ridicule, embarrass, or draw attention to the actions of politicians and celebrities. This form of protest gained prominence in the late 20th century, with activists targeting political and cultural figures to challenge authority through humor and spectacle. Belgian anarchist Noël Godin popularized “patisserie guerrilla,” turning pie-throwing into an art form. Groups like the Biotic Baking Brigade in the U.S. have used pieing to protest against perceived greed or corruption among “titans of power.” Notable incidents span decades, involving figures from William F. Buckley Jr. and Anita Bryant to Bill Gates, highlighting the endurance of this tactic.
